newsitem.title: USA: US SEC sees fee collections up despite rate drop.
newsitem.headline: US SEC sees fee collections up despite rate drop.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday it expects fee collections to rise in fiscal 1998, despite lower fee rates, because of one-time circumstances and an anticipated increase in market activity.
The agency's budget estimate projects $996.5 million in fee revenue for the year beginning October 1, up from estimated collections of $795.3 million in the current fiscal year.
Total fee collections for 1998 would amount to 314 percent of the SEC's requested budget of $317.4 million. But in later years, it said it expects fee collections to decline.

Of the total, $572.6 million is expected from securities registration fees in fiscal 1998, up from $546.2 million in fiscal 1997. The projected increase anticipates a higher volume of registrations that will more than offset a congressionally mandated cut in the fee rate for fiscal 1998 to 1/34 of 1 percent from 1/33 of 1 percent, SEC officials said.

Fees on securities transactions are expected to rise to $400.9 million from $226 million because of special one-time events in which 1998 collections cover a wider period of time and because of growth in market activity, they said.
The SEC is not seeking budget hikes for enforcement or for its Electronic Data Gathering And Retrieval (EDGAR) service.
